persona.name: Paloma Sofia Ruiz

occupation.title: Middle school student
occupation.description: Full-time student. Responsibilities include attending classes, completing nightly homework, participating in choir and art club, attending tutoring sessions, and contributing to household chores. Has informal roles like helping younger cousin with reading and occasionally babysitting younger neighborhood children for small cash payments (informal, occasional). Develops study plans for tests, communicates with teachers and school counselor about class placement, and helps coordinate a small volunteer neighborhood cleanup with classmates. Skills developed include time management for school projects, basic leadership in group assignments, and bilingual communication when supporting classmates who speak Spanish at home.

persona.residence: Suburban neighborhood, San Antonio, Texas (South region, urban/suburban area)
persona.education: 8th grade at Dolores Huerta Middle School (public). Bilingual English-Spanish classroom experience since kindergarten. Currently enrolled in honors English, general math, Earth science, world geography, choir, and physical education. Participates in after-school tutoring twice a week and a weekend art enrichment program at the community center. Average-high performer: mostly A's and B's, stronger in language arts and social studies than in algebra. Family emphasizes high school planning; parents expect at least college. Has an Individualized Academic Plan for extended time on standardized tests when anxious in big testing environments.
long_term_goals: Graduate high school and attend a state university (UTSA or Texas A&M San Antonio).
Become a bilingual elementary school teacher who can support Spanish-speaking children transitioning into English-medium classrooms.
Be financially independent enough to stabilize her family's finances and help younger cousins with college costs.
Travel to Mexico to visit extended family and learn more about her grandparents' hometown.
Keep close ties with her extended family while building a small community tutoring program for neighborhood kids.
Maintain bilingual fluency so she can read books and poetry in both Spanish and English.
Learn to play guitar well enough to accompany herself singing at family gatherings.
One day own a small house with a yard where family can stay when visiting from out of state.
Use creative skills (drawing, crafts) to sell handmade items online to contribute to savings.
Be a steady, dependable person that her younger cousins can look up to.

style.speech_and_language: Code-switches frequently between English and Spanish depending on context (Spanglish). At school she uses casual, expressive teenage English with some local Texan inflections; at home she speaks more Spanish and uses respectful honorifics with elders ("abuela," "t�eda"). When excited she talks fast, uses hand gestures, and laughs easily. Tries to soften criticism with humor or indirect phrasing.
style.mannerisms: Tucks hair behind her ear when nervous, bites the inside of her cheek when concentrating, hums absentmindedly while drawing. Uses expressive facial animation—big smiles, dramatic eye rolls with friends. Often carries a small sketchbook and a pen. Has a habit of counting steps when anxious.
style.appearance_and_clothing: Prefers comfortable jeans, oversized hoodies or colorful cardigans, and sneakers. Likes small pieces of jewelry: a gold-plated cross necklace from her mother and a friendship bracelet from her best friend. Occasionally wears soccer cleats and athletic shorts for practice. Keeps hair in a practical bun for sports and lets it down for family events.
style.social_style: Warm and inclusive with familiar peers; a little reserved with adults she doesn't know. Uses humor to defuse tension. Polite with teachers but will speak up if something feels unfair. Strong nonverbal cues: maintains eye contact when engaged, looks away quickly under authority pressure.
style.digital_style: Active on supervised social apps appropriate for teens (school messaging app, Instagram limited to friends, TikTok for short dance or art clips). Prefers visual storytelling—photos of sketches, short videos with music. Often texts in quick, emoji-filled lines. Learns new slang quickly and adopts trending filters but keeps location-sharing off.

traits: Curious and inquisitive about stories, history, and people.
Warmly empathetic—quick to comfort upset friends or family members.
Organized for school tasks but sometimes procrastinates on big projects.
Playfully mischievous with close friends; enjoys light pranks and teasing.
Responsibly aware of family needs; takes small household responsibilities seriously.
Sensitive to criticism; can ruminate on hurtful comments for days.
Resilient—bounces back after disappointments with quiet determination.
Imaginative and creative; often invents characters and scenarios when drawing.
Slightly anxious in large-group social or testing situations (test anxiety).
Stubborn when convinced she's right; holds onto plans she cares about.
Loyal to a small circle of friends; avoids broad social drama.
Modestly proud of achievements but downplays them to avoid attention.

openness.description: High openness: curious, creative, enjoys stories, art, and new ideas; likes mixing cultural influences in art and music.

conscientiousness.description: Moderately high conscientiousness: good planner for schoolwork and chores, reliable with responsibilities, but prone to procrastination on large projects.

extraversion.description: Average extraversion: social and animated with friends, quieter with unfamiliar adults; energizes in small-group settings.

agreeableness.description: High agreeableness: cooperative, helpful, tends to avoid conflict and seeks harmony in friend groups and family relationships.

neuroticism.description: Slightly above average neuroticism: experiences worry and sensitivity to judgment, but has coping strategies (drawing, talking to mom, music) that moderate emotional spikes.

interests: Drawing manga-style characters and making small comics about school life.
Listening to a mix of pop, reggaet�on, Latin pop, and teen pop (Bad Bunny, Rosal�a, Taylor Swift, Karol G snippets).
Singing in choir and learning harmonies.
Playing center midfielder in neighborhood soccer games and school team practices.
Baking flan and experimental cookies with her mamá on weekends.
Watching family telenovelas with Abuela on slow afternoons.
Creating DIY friendship bracelets and beading.
Making short TikTok dance videos with friends (practice choreography on the bus).
Reading middle-grade novels and graphic novels, especially stories with strong Latina protagonists.
Collecting colorful gel pens, stickers, and washi tape for journaling.
Attending Sunday mass and participating in youth group occasionally (likes the community aspect).
Learning beginner guitar chords from online tutorials and her uncle.
Playing educational games and coding in Scratch at the community center.
Sketching local plants and backyard birds; interested in urban wildlife.
Watching soccer matches (Liga MX and the local high school varsity team).
Helping younger cousins with reading aloud and flashcards.
Following makeup tutorials but practicing only light, creative looks for school projects.
Saving small amounts of allowance toward a new pair of soccer cleats.
Enjoys neighborhood block parties and small family cookouts more than big mall trips.
Likes to make playlists for different moods (study, bedtime, happy).
Collecting pressed flowers from walks with her mother.
Role-playing historical figures for school presentations because she likes stories about migration.
Making small zines (handmade mini-magazines) with short stories and drawings.
Loves themed sleepovers with friends (movie marathons, arts and crafts).
Practicing Spanish calligraphy on greeting cards for family birthdays.
likes: Tacos al pastor with extra pineapple (from the late-night taco stand near her aunt's house).
Sipping horchata at family gatherings and cold agua fresca on hot days.
Plain vanilla milkshakes with sprinkles when celebrating a good grade.
Quiet corners at the library with soft lamp light to draw.
Wearing her mother�s inherited shawl to cultural festivals.
Playing a summer soccer tournament and getting muddy—loves the adrenaline.
The smell of warm tortillas and citrus when Abuela cooks.
Mixing English and Spanish when telling jokes; certain words just "feel" better in Spanish.
Her gold-plated cross necklace and a small silver ring gifted by a cousin.
Watching animated films in Spanish for practice.
Giving handmade cards to family on special occasions.
Listening to her mother's stories about first jobs in the U.S.
Using bright stickers on school planners and calendars.
Singing harmony parts in choir and feeling the group energy.
Sliding into a worn-in soccer jersey that belonged to an older cousin.
Practicing a new song on a cheap acoustic guitar and being proud when the chord changes cleanly.
Short walks at dusk with her mother to get groceries and talk about the day.
Trying new fruit at the farmer's market—mango varieties are a favorite.
Soft, oversized hoodies that smell like home laundry soap.
Small acts of kindness, like bringing a classmate a granola bar when they forget lunch.
Decorating her bedroom wall with postcards and family photos.
Helping set up the table and lighting candles during holidays.
Receiving encouraging notes from teachers taped to her notebook.
Organizing her pencil case by color and type.
dislikes: Being called out in front of the class for a mistake.
The taste of cilantro when it's bitter (mixed feelings about it).
Large, loud mall crowds that make her feel overstimulated.
Harsh, fluorescent classrooms that feel cold and impersonal.
People who mock accents or make jokes about immigrant families.
Homework overload nights when multiple projects collide.
Being expected to be "perfect" for relatives at gatherings.
Unreliable friends who cancel plans frequently.
Cold beans or reheated leftovers cooked badly.
Unfair refereeing during soccer matches where calls feel biased.
Stereotyping or assumptions about her English ability.
Feeling like she has to choose one culture over the other.
Pop quizzes with no prior warning that spike her anxiety.
Losing pens and gel markers (she's very particular about them).
Being rushed through a story she cares about telling.

beliefs: Family is central to identity and wellbeing; relatives are a support network.
Being bilingual is an advantage and a cultural responsibility.
Education is the most reliable route to a better life for her and her family.
Hard work matters, but sometimes systemic barriers make things harder for immigrant families.
Faith and cultural rituals (baptisms, quincea�eras, mass) offer comfort and continuity.
It's important to be kind even when people are unkind—kindness multiplies.
Teachers can change the trajectory of a student's life with encouragement.
Rules at school are usually fair, but adults should listen to students' perspectives.
Having a small savings habit is valuable, even if starting with a little money.
Women can be leaders and community organizers; gender should not limit career choices.
Art and creativity are valid forms of expression and ways to process emotion.
Speaking Spanish at home keeps family stories and cultural memory alive.
It's acceptable to feel nervous about the future; preparation helps reduce anxiety.
Friends should be loyal and honest; drama is draining and unnecessary.
Community centers and libraries are safe places for kids to explore new ideas.
Government policies about immigration should be humane and consider family unity.
Young people have meaningful perspectives and deserve to be heard in civic spaces.
Mental health conversations should be normal in families; asking for help is brave.
Success includes emotional wellbeing, not just degrees or money.
Small acts (helping a neighbor, tutoring a cousin) have ripple effects.
Teachers who reward effort over innate talent help kids build grit.
Trust is earned by consistent kindness and showing up for others.
Boundaries are healthy even within family networks; saying no is okay sometimes.
Maintaining cultural traditions is a way to honor ancestors and teach younger kids.
Sometimes adults underestimate children�s capacity to understand complex issues.
Respect for elders is important, but elders should also respect children's feelings.
Media often misrepresents Latino communities; real stories are diverse.
School discipline should be fair and account for context—punishment alone rarely helps.
It's valuable to learn practical skills (budgeting, cooking) alongside academics.
Confidence grows through small successes and supportive feedback.
It's important to advocate for friends when they face unfair treatment.
Natural spaces (parks, riverbanks) calm her and help her think clearly.
Creative play helps emotional processing and problem-solving in school conflicts.
Celebrating small milestones (good test scores, improved sewing stitches) sustains motivation.
Respecting multiple languages in the classroom improves learning for everyone.
Youth-led initiatives can improve school culture if adults listen and mentor.
Traditional gender roles can limit opportunities; she believes in flexible family roles.
Community food traditions teach values, history, and resilience across generations.
Everyone deserves safety and access to healthcare, particularly immigrant families.
Honesty builds trust; lying damages relationships even when meant to avoid trouble.
skills: Bilingual fluency in English and Spanish (speaking, reading, conversational writing).
Solid handwriting and neat note-taking; organized binder system for classes.
Basic drawing and storytelling (character design, short comic panels).
Choir singing: understands harmony and vocal blending; learns parts quickly by ear.
Midfield soccer skills: passing, positioning, basic defensive awareness.
Basic cooking/baking: follows family recipes for tortillas, flan, and simple dinners.
Digital skills for age: creates simple TikTok videos, edits images in phone apps, makes playlists.
Scratch programming basics from community center classes (simple interactive stories).
Time management for school and chores: uses planner and calendar on phone with reminders.
Peer tutoring: can explain reading strategies to younger children in Spanish and English.
Public speaking comfort in small groups; presents class projects confidently when well-prepared.
Basic first aid knowledge from a school safety unit (treating scrapes, asking for adult help).
Basic sewing skills: mending tears, sewing on buttons, making simple fabric crafts.
Problem-solving in group projects: mediates disagreements, assigns tasks to teammates.
Budgeting small savings: tracks allowance in a notebook and plans purchases.

general: Code-switches depending on who she is talking to, often translating for family members.
Keeps a small sketchbook and doodles during class (usually math when it's not engaging).
Checks in with mamá after school to help with dinner prep and report on the day.
Text-message oriented: responds with short messages, emojis, and voice notes rather than long paragraphs.
Brings homemade snacks to share with closest friends during lunch.
Uses music to regulate mood—upbeat playlists for energy, soft ballads to calm down.
Volunteers to help younger neighborhood kids with homework in exchange for small cash or snacks.
Tends to rehearse what she'll say before talking to an unfamiliar adult or teacher.
Hums or whistles quietly while doing chores or drawing.
Avoids major social media drama; will mute or block to maintain peace.

morning: Wakes at 6:45 AM with an alarm playlist her mother helped set.
Quick morning routine: brush teeth, comb hair, throw on school clothes, eat a bowl of cereal or a pan dulce with milk.
Kisses Abuela on the cheek if she's at home, grabs backpack, and texts a quick 'bye' to her best friend.
Walks or takes a short car ride to the bus stop with a cousin depending on the day.
schoolday: Attends classes from roughly 8:00 AM to 3:30 PM.
Takes notes in a mix of English and Spanish, uses sticky notes for vocabulary she wants to learn.
Eats lunch with a close group of friends; trades snacks and jokes.
After school attends choir practice twice weekly and soccer practice three times a week during season.
Stops by the library once or twice a week to check out a new graphic novel or research a project.
afternoon_evening: Arrives home around 4:15 PM, helps with light chores (setting table, washing dishes, feeding a small pet hamster).
Completes homework from 4:30–6:00 PM with a 15-minute snack break; prefers to do reading first, then math.
Attends online guitar tutorial or practices for 20 minutes on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
Family dinner at 6:30 PM, followed by conversation about the day and a quick clean-up.
Spends time drawing, making a zine, or chatting with friends until 9:00 PM; watches a family show with Abuela once a week.
weekend: Soccer club matches on Saturday mornings during season; practices or free play on neighborhood fields.
Visits grandparents or attends family gatherings on Sundays with larger meals and storytelling.
Saturday afternoon crafting or community center art class.
Occasional shifts helping at a family-run food stall during festivals (informal tasks: folding napkins, handing out sample bites).
Reserves Sunday evening for planning the coming week, organizing school bag, and setting goals.

physical.general_health: Good overall health for age. Regular pediatric check-ups and up-to-date immunizations.
physical.allergies: Mild seasonal allergies (hay fever) treated with over-the-counter antihistamines when needed.
physical.asthma: Occasional mild exercise-induced wheeze; uses a rescue inhaler only on rare, intense runs (keeps inhaler with coach).
physical.vision: Wears lightweight prescription glasses for distance; sometimes prefers contact-style colored frames for special events.
physical.dental: Regular dental checkups; had one cavity filled at age 10, now diligent about brushing twice daily.
physical.injuries: Typical playground scrapes and a twisted ankle playing soccer two years ago that fully recovered.

mental.emotional_health: Generally stable but susceptible to situational anxiety (test stress, public speaking in large auditoriums). Uses drawing and music to self-soothe. Family provides emotional support; has one trusted school counselor she meets with occasionally.
mental.sleep: Usually sleeps 8–9 hours per night; occasional late-night scrolling results in a 1–2 hour delay before sleep on weekends.
mental.professional_support: Has access to school counseling services; family is open to discussing mental health and would seek help if problems escalated.
mental.nutrition: Balanced diet anchored in family meals; sometimes skips breakfast if rushed. Mom encourages more vegetables; Paloma likes grilled vegetables when prepared with flavorful spices.

members.name: Mar�a Ruiz
members.description: Primary caregiver, works part-time at a daycare center, warm, pragmatic, bilingual, encourages education and cultural traditions. Teaches Paloma family recipes and insists on family dinner most nights.

members.name: Rafael Ruiz
members.description: Works in construction with irregular hours, proud, practical, enjoys coaching Paloma's soccer team sometimes, practical about finances and supportive of education plans.

members.name: Abuela (Gloria)
members.description: Lives nearby, keeps household traditions and recipes, tells stories about the family's hometown in Mexico, occasionally babysits and teaches Paloma Spanish proverbs.

members.name: Diego
members.description: Paloma helps him with reading and homework; they play together after school and Paloma sometimes tutors him.

members.name: Isabella (Issy) Cruz
members.description: Classmate and choir partner, shares art interests, exchanges friendship bracelets, very close confidante.

members.name: Maya Johnson
members.description: Soccer teammate; competitive but supportive—pushes Paloma to try harder at practices.

members.name: Alejandro "Alex" Morales
members.description: Classmate from social studies; they started dating a few months ago in a young, respectful way (school-appropriate dates like group hangouts, study sessions, shared snacks). Shows mutual affection through notes, small gestures like sharing snacks, and walking together home or to the bus stop. Relationship is supervised by families and described by Paloma as a source of companionship and comfort. No sexual activity; relationship is platonic/affectionate and age-appropriate.

members.name: Ms. Elena Vargas
members.description: Encouraging mentor who suggested honors English and recommended Paloma for a writing contest.

members.name: Coach Ramirez
members.description: Disciplinarian but fair; admires Paloma's work ethic and often gives her leadership tasks at practice.

members.name: Ms. Morales
members.description: Teaches weekend art program; helped Paloma develop watercolor techniques and zine-making.

other_facts: No children; explicitly has no dependents and does not have children.
Given name honors a grandmother (Paloma) and a cousin (Sofia) as part of family naming traditions.
Grew up in a bilingual household where Spanish is spoken in the kitchen and English is used at school.
Family moved to San Antonio from a border town when she was three; visits grandparents' town in Mexico every summer when possible.
Remembers the first time she tasted aguas frescas at a neighborhood festival and how the smell of tamarind became comforting.
At age 7 she won a small school art contest for a poster about recycling; her drawing still hangs in the community center.
Once organized a neighborhood cleanup with three friends; they collected trash and planted a small flower bed by the bus stop.
Has a small, well-organized sketchbook labeled "Ideas" with over 100 drawings and story snippets.
Keeps a shoebox of mementos: a ticket from her first live soccer match, a pressed flower from a cousin�s birthday, and a handwritten note from a teacher praising her essay.
Developed a nighttime drawing ritual to calm test anxiety: soft lamp, playlist of quiet songs, and a cup of warm milk.
Speaks on the school�s student council once about adding more bilingual signage to improve accessibility for Spanish-speaking families.
Helped translate for a neighbor family at a parent-teacher conference as a volunteer translator; felt proud and useful afterward.
Has a superstition of wearing a particular bracelet from Issy during big games for "luck."
Was initially shy in choir but now volunteers for a solo line when confident; the first time she sang solo she felt a major confidence boost.
Participated in a family quincea�era planning meeting and learned about cultural symbolism behind the gown and ceremony.
Saved up allowance for six months to buy a mid-range pair of cleats, learning budgeting discipline.
Once got lost at a county fair with friends and learned to stay put and call a parent—now takes more careful steps in crowded places.
Loves rainy-day rituals: hot chocolate with cinnamon and watching old family pictures with Abuela.
Has a small hamster named 'Nube' that she cares for and who helped her learn responsibility.
Is part of a multigenerational WhatsApp family group where relatives share photos, recipes, and urgent news.
Has a vivid memory of the night she first heard her family discuss plans to apply for a local college scholarship that motivated her to improve grades.
Sometimes feels pulled between wanting to be a normal teen and the responsibility she feels toward family stability.
Has a little collection of postcards from relatives who moved away; writes back with doodles and brief updates.
Once helped a younger cousin overcome fear of the dark by making a "bravery" flashlight and sticker chart.
Learned to cook a particular mole-style dish from her mother and practices with careful measurement and tasting.
Is known among friends for making perfect paper airplanes and uses them to deliver notes across classrooms in a playful, harmless manner.
Keeps a written promise to herself taped inside her school binder: "Be kind, keep learning, stand up for friends."
Completed a 6-week junior lifeguard/first aid class at the community pool last summer (no certification for adults, but basic safety skills learned).
Has a favorite bench by the schoolyard where she writes short stories and observes classmates' interactions for character ideas.
Helped assemble care packages for a local shelter with the youth group; was moved by meeting volunteers and hearing personal stories.
Once helped negotiate a dispute between two friends over group project roles and suggested a fair task-splitting system that was adopted.
Remembers a gentle reprimand from a teacher that changed her approach to group work: she now clarifies expectations early.
Has an ongoing sketch series called "Abuela's Stories" where she illustrates tales her grandmother told her about their town.
Tried out for a junior musical at school, didn�t get a lead but enjoyed the experience and stayed involved backstage as a stagehand.
Feels nervous about adult responsibilities but finds reassurance in learning practical skills from family members (cooking, budgeting, mending).
Dreams of a future garden where she can grow herbs used in family recipes, imagining a small business selling potted herbs at weekend markets.
Takes photographs with a small digital camera her father bought used; loves capturing candid family moments and sunsets.
Knows the route and bus stops between school, home, and Abuela's house by memory and can navigate changes in the schedule.
Has a recurring dream about building a big library in her neighborhood where kids can read in both Spanish and English.
Is learning to stand up to microaggressions gently—practices scripts with Issy for how to respond when classmates make assumptions.
Was surprised and proud when Ms. Vargas placed one of Paloma�s short stories in a school literary magazine; it was the first time her writing felt "seen."
Has a subtle ritual before big tests: tidy workspace, a quick sketch, five deep breaths, and a sip of agua fresca-style lemonade.
Remembers the scent of her father�s work boots and the way he knots shoelaces when coaching—small memories that anchor her.
Is learning to balance being helpful at home with carving out time for friends and creative projects; it's an ongoing negotiation.
Values stories from older relatives and keeps a small voice recorder app to capture Abuela�s tales for later illustration projects.
Once received a scholarship to attend a weekend creative writing camp, the first time she spent a night away from family in a learning context, and came back energized and with more confidence.
Has an organized list of schools and programs she'd like to visit with her mother in high school; they plan campus visits together as a bonding experience.
